Madam Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs.
After studying the cost of over 3.5 million prescriptions, covering 16,000 drugs worth over $1 billion, the Green Shield report clearly shows that Canadians have been misled and that drug prices have been rising in Canada at an annual rate of over 11 per cent.
My question to the minister is this. Why does the minister and his government continue to deny and obstruct the fact that they have completely failed in their responsibilities to protect Canadian consumers from unwarranted rises in the cost of prescription drugs?

House leader said, and I quote: "The Drug Prices Review Board will ensure that prices are reasonable and do not get out of line".

Given that the price has not gone up by one penny but has gone up by 11 per cent every year since 1987, why did the government mislead Canadians on such a fundamentally important health issue to all Canadian families?

from 1990 levels by the year 2005 to be achieved by co-ordinated global efforts". Has the government accepted that recommendation and will it be working for it in Brazil?

Since the June 1990 announcement of the Minister of the Environment that cabinet policies would be subjected to an environmental impact assessment and that a public statement would be released, (a) which policies have been subjected to environmental impact assessments (b) who conducted each assessment (c) when and how was, or will, the public statement be released?
May 15, 1992

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean J. Charest (Minister of the Environment):
maintopic: CANADA MORTGAGE AND HOUSING CORPORATION ACT
speechtext:
As the hon. member knows, policy and program proposals, where appropriate, are advanced for cabinet review, after consideration of the environmental implications of such proposals. Of course, when the analysis shows that no significant environmental effect is anticipated as a result of a certain proposal, that conclusion is indicated and no further elaboration or statement is required.
Some examples of recent policies and programs that included a rather substantial environmental assessment which supports the early integration of environmental considerations in the decision-making process, include:
The Canadian Policy on Nuclear Vessels in Canadian Waters which examined the environmental considerations and effects of visits of nuclear-powered vessels to Canadian ports; and
The Transit of Dixon Entrance by U.S. submarines, a policy for which an environmental assessment was an integral part of the decision.
Of course, on the program proposals side, all program initiatives proposed under the green plan-77 to date- were subjected to an environmental assessment at the planning stage.
Similarly, Agriculture Canada integrated an environmental assessment of the Farm Safety Net Program.
In addition, an environmental review of the North America free trade agreement is being conducted by this government.
In response to the question of who conducts each assessment, it is the initiating minister of the policy or program that is responsible for ensuring that the integration, quality, and timeliness of the environmental assessment is considered fully and early in the decision process.
The public statements are released at the same time as the government's policy or program initiatives are announced. Supporting studies or documents are referred to in these statements. For some of the policy proposals cited above, the entire studies were referred to and made available to the public.

speechtext: Agreed.

The House resumed consideration of the motion of Mr. Andre that Bill C-73, an act to amend the Canada Post Corporation Act, be read a second time and referred to a legislative committee in the Departmental envelope; and the amendment of Mr. Boudria (p. 10744).

Madam Speaker, it is an interesting bill we are debating here today. It is one of these bills that in the future we would always be able to go back to, if the government had the opportunity to govern much longer, which it will not, and there would be a wealth of denials about the actual intent of the government when it introduces pieces of legislation.
I listened with a great deal of amusement to the minister responsible and some of his colleagues opposite. They gave eloquent speeches in the House today on those wonderful employees of Canada Post Corporation.
All I can ask is, why did it take you so long to realize that the people who work at Canada Post Corporation are indeed wonderful public servants who deserve some
respect from this government and deliver a tremendous service to all Canadians?
A member opposite was speaking just prior to Question Period, and I was almost apoplectic in my chair. He was talking about the wonderful service and what terribly efficient people work at the Canada Post Corporation. He even had to delve into the Never Never Land of the North Pole and Santa Claus. All these wonderful men and women that work at Canada Post even process mail that comes with the postal code HOH OHO. I say to him: "Oh, oh, oh".
He converted himself on the road to Damascus on this issue, because the record of this government in dealing with those wonderful public servants who are just trying to get a decent day's pay for an honest day's work has been absolutely abysmal.
The government got up today and got its members up like trained seals to read memorandums and speeches written by the department saying: "Forgive us, forgive us, forgive us, we know not what we have done. We really did not mean to kick you all over the mat and all over the carpet, you employees of Canada Post".
It is saying: "Yes, we finally realize that you are nice people and are deserving of some praise from the government, your employer in this country", but that is not the way it has been. To deny the past is not something I will allow the government to do here.
The Canada Post Corporation is perhaps the one service that touches every single Canadian because hopefully at some point in your life you are going to receive a letter from somebody. Every month I get too many bills from a whole lot of people and maybe a few letters as well.
Canada Post is one of the most visible signs of the Government of Canada for the people of our nation. The postman used to ring the door bell. We used to be proud that we had a national system of mail delivery which was second to none anywhere in the world. We used to talk about how proud our public servants were to deliver that service for Canadians from the Canadian postal service, Canada Post.
When the government led by Brian Mulroney came in, and I do not have the quotes here but I put them to the record often enough, the reckless rhetoric of the Prime Minister leading up to the 1984 election should have
May 15, 1992

given us a signal of what his true intent was in terms of the Public Service in Canada, including those public servants at Canada Post.
He talked at length about how there would be pink slips issued everywhere. We all remember those quotes from the election campaign. The master of hyperbole on the other side of the House, the great Prime Minister of Canada, was going to clean out the House, he was going to teach those nasty old public servants and post office workers a lesson.
He was saying: "Torydom is in town and fear for your jobs. You are going to be the scapegoat of everything we do wrong. You are going to be vilified by this government because you are an easy mark and an easy target". That is exactly what the Tories did.
We saw the great postal service of Canada dismantled piece by piece, letter by letter, by this government opposite.
The government first of all announced that in urban areas there would be no more delivery to new homes. There is the unbelievable situation in places like Dartmouth, where a small piece of the community had not yet been developed residentially. Maybe it was a fanner's field, or maybe it was something else. Maybe it was just not developed. Everybody around them has been getting mail for 100 years. Now somebody puts a new street in and they do not get door-to-door delivery any more. This Conservative government with its penchant for cutting back and its absolute desire to destroy anything Canadian, anything that every Canadian could reach out and touch and say: "That is what makes me a Canadian". It put in supermailboxes. In the middle of some of the biggest cities we have supermailboxes. Is that not wonderful. I pay the same price for my postal service as the person down the road, but the person down the road gets supermailboxes.
Back when I was elected the post office was a big issue. People wanted to know how the Liberal Party would deal with Canada Post, whether the Liberal Party was committed to reinstating door-to-door delivery, or whether the Liberal Party would ensure that in rural Canada, where the post office is the most visible and perhaps the only symbol of this national government, we would not abandon them.
Government Orders
There have been thousands and thousands of petitions presented to this Parliament since I got elected.
Places like Cow Head.

My hon. friend from Newfoundland says places like Cow Head. I was in Cow Head. Those people have been abandoned. They have been abandoned because Canada Post made a decision that came right from the mouth of the government babes opposite in the front benches that it was going to dismantle Canada Post and not run it as a service, but run it as a business.
If that means that some Canadians can expect to get less service than other Canadians then so be it. If that means breaking the backs of the unions then so be it. If it means raising the price of a stamp as high it can dare go then so be it. If it means Canada Post acquiring companies and competing with good private sector companies, such as courier services, then so be it. If it means having the president of a Crown corporation, Canada Post, who does not feel that he is responsible to anybody but God, and maybe not even to God, then so be it. That is what this government has set about to do.
We have seen an erosion in mail service right across Canada. The government can give you all kinds of statistics. Maybe in an urban area like mine it is okay. Maybe people do not mind going down to the IGA to buy their stamps or pick up their parcels, maybe they do not. However, in a rural area the post office was not just a building where you picked up your mail; it was a symbol of Canada. In many of those communities all over Canada, in the prairies, the only visible sign of the Government of Canada, of this great nation of ours, of this great institution of Parliament, was the post office. The Tories did not have any mandate from the Canadian public to shut it down, to deliver it to the hands of the private sector. However, that is exactly what it has done.
In the last few years we have seen the government develop a policy, an abominable policy, to go into areas of our Public Service and make people feel that they are no longer welcome to contribute their day's labour for the meagre pay they get. It means going into places like Canada Post and allowing the president of Canada Post and some of the people he has put around him to go in and poison the atmosphere between labour and management to such an extent that last year, a year and a half

May 15, 1992
Government Orders
ago, there were nearly 100,000 grievances in Canada Post.
This is our government. This is our government's own postal service. This is the government that passes laws, that dictates the procedures that are acceptable and are not acceptable for workers on job sites. Yet in this corporation, which it owns, it has poisoned the atmosphere so badly that pregnant women down in the Gateway plant in metropolitan Toronto were not given permission to go to the washroom. That was two years ago. Racial discrimination was a practice in postal sorting stations in other parts of the country. Grievances that should have been settled right there on the workshop floor were forced into the grievance procedure. That was not by accident. It was by grand design.
This government is hell-bent on, and I have said it since 1988, privatizing Canada's postal service.
If that means delivering it to the highest bidder and that highest bidder happens to be an American south of the border, as much as I love my American neighbours down south, I do not want them delivering my mail in Dartmouth.
What the government has done here is a little sleight of hand. It has come in and said: "Look, here is what we are going to do here. We are going to sell off 10 per cent of the shares"-whatever the heck that means-"of Canada Post. We are going to let the employees buy into it".
The hon. member opposite said: "We think that if we allow them to take part of the ownership of the corporation, it will motivate them to provide better service. We think that it would give them a sense of entrepreneurial spirit. We think it would deliver a sense of commitment".
The hon. member opposite talked earlier about the awarding of medals and talked about some postal worker down in Atlantic Canada, I think it was in Halifax, who did something that he considered extraordinary. He went beyond the call of duty. If this government were not on a search and destroy mission on the unions of Canada Post, which it has been on since it was elected, it would have recognized that what he was talking about today was not the exception, it was the rule and it still is the rule in most of the postal service in Canada. Those
people do not have horns. They are just like you and I. They are trying to make a decent day's pay for a decent day's labour and they do not want to be harassed on the worksite and they do not want to have grievances filed and they do not want medals from the government.
All they want is a little respect for the job that they do on behalf of each and every Canadian. That is all they want. They do not need shares in a corporation that they already own as Canadians to have a sense of pride and commitment to their work. As a Canadian citizen, each and every one of those employees does own that Crown corporation because it is owned by the Government of Canada.
Let us strip this bill down for what it is. It is nothing short of a scam. It is a waste of time even to be debating the damned thing if it were not so important that we try to uncover the government's true agenda here. The government's true agenda here is not to motivate its employees. Can you imagine? I was almost waiting for elevator music to be played in the background while the hon. member eloquently professed this new-found love for the postal workers in Canada.
This bill is the first step on the slippery slope to privatizing the Canada Post Corporation. That is what it is. One of the members opposite is smiling. He is probably smiling because he knows I am on to them. He is smiling because he is not running again. He knows that what I am saying now is not going to affect him. He has probably already got his pension, he is okay.
What this does is it brings into legislation a process that was begun a few years ago. If you break the union's spirit, if you convince the Canadian public that these people really do not give them good service anyway, and then if you mandate the Crown corporation to increase rates, get into competition in the private sector so that it can improve its profit line, it makes it more attractive when you want to sell the darned thing off.
The government, if it were ever allowed to govern again after the next election, it would bring another bill in and would ask: "What is so different? We already started this thing. We gave 10 per cent to the employees. I do not know why the opposition is complaining and bellyaching".
May 15, 1992

The opposition is complaining and bellyaching because not everything can be run exactly like a business when you have a country like Canada. You cannot run everything exactly like a business. You cannot run the country exactly like a business. You have to run it as a nation. To run it as a nation means that there are costs incurred. To run it as a nation also means that you have to understand the requirements, the desires and the aspirations of those people whom you govern. This gang opposite has lost all sense of sensibility on that score. We all know that. It was jumping for joy last week because it was at 16 per cent in the polls. Can you imagine? Just think how it is going to jump if it ever hits 18 per cent.
We had the president of Canada Post at the consumer and corporate affairs committee. It was an experience. I have never heard so many words say so little in all my life.
We wanted to find out whether Canada Post was in the business of providing service or if it was in the business of improving its profit line so that it could ostensibly sell itself in the public sector, in the private sector.
One of the things that we looked at was the courier service. Maybe I am a little dense but I thought Canada Post's responsibility, since it had a monopoly on first-class mail, was to deliver first-class mail. I did not think that the responsibility of a Crown corporation, which has the weight of the public purse behind it, was to go and compete with private sector corporations. That is exactly what this corporation has done.
This corporation is cross-subsidizing a courier service, Priority Courier Service. It has now been able, through cross-subsidization from the profits on its first-class mail service, to go in and capture 25 per cent of the courier market in Canada.
Everybody here and out there probably watched something dealing with the Olympics. I asked the president why he would be getting into private sector areas which are well served, in private sector areas where people are losing jobs now because the market has softened because of this government's induced recession. Why would he be getting in as a Crown corporation and competing with those individuals? It is a business decision, he said.
Government Orders
"Are you taking money", I asked, "from the monopoly that you get on first-class mail and all the profits that ensue and pumping it over into your courier service, basically undercutting predatory pricing and undercutting your competition?" "Never would we do that", the president said.
I asked if Canada Post did any advertising in the Olympics. He said it did. When I asked him how much, he said that was confidential information. I watched the Olympics and I cannot remember once seeing an ad from Canada Post, but I remember seeing all kinds of ads from the courier service which is competing with private sector courier services and putting many of them out of business in small towns in Canada.
Now the president of Canada Post knows what his mandate is. It is to make the company as profitable as he can. If that means a loss of service in rural Canada, so be it. If it means higher prices, so be it. If it means dismantling the corporation, so be it. If it means predatory pricing practices on the private sector, so be it. The ultimate goal of this government is to privatize Canada Post.
I can foresee the day, if we ever gave these guys opposite another chance, that UPS would be delivering mail to my door by a fellow with an American flag on his lapel or on his shoulder. I can see that day if these guys opposite have their way.
Get serious.

The hon. member opposite said to get serious. I am very, very serious. The hon. member opposite knows full well what the government's intent is. If he were honest with himself and his constituents he would tell them. If the intent of the government in this bill is try to motivate the employees of Canada Post to be more productive and to feel that they have a better say in what goes on, treat them with a little bit of respect. Do not be forcing them through the grievance procedure every time something happens on the floor of the post office. You do not have to bring a bill into Parliament, you just have to have some respect in the way that you treat the people of Canada Post.
The hon. member opposite knows this because he was the chairman of the consumer and corporate affairs committee. When the Liberal task force on Canada Post was conducting hearings, he came and sat in on some of the hearings and he expressed to me his concern about

May 15, 1992
Government Orders
the way Canada Post management was handling some of those grievances at the shop floor level. I want to remind him of that.
This bill here is awful. This bill seeks through the back door and through the premise that the government is trying to help the employees, to de-stabilize and start us on the slippery slope to privatization of Canada Post. It is not a bill I am going to support.
I believe that Canada Post has a primary responsibility to offer quality service to Canadians. I am not opposed to Canada Post's mandate being changed to suit changing times. I am opposed to Canada Post's getting involved in the private sector. They are all supposed to be private sector people over there. They all jump up and down and say: "Private sector, private sector". If they are so concerned about the private sector, get Canada Post out of the business of competing with private courier services across Canada for a start and start preserving some jobs. You cannot speak out of both sides of your mouth all the time, although a lot of members opposite try that all the time. I find that they bite their lip a lot.
I cannot support this bill. I know what this bill is all about and the Canadian public knows what this bill is all about. No matter what flowery language those converted on the road to Damascus opposite are going to use in this debate, those individuals who work at Canada Post will judge the gang opposite by its record and not by its rhetoric.
The record has been abysmal. It has crushed the spirits of people who wanted to work at Canada Post. It has driven people out and a once proud, productive and wonderful place to work, Canada Post, has become a nightmare for most of those employees.
In conclusion, let me say I would hope that the people listening out there do not get sucked in once again by another Tory promise that this is going to improve service. Remember what they said and judge them accordingly the next time you go to the polls.

Madam Speaker, I did not want to stop this show. This gentleman is about to graduate from the George Baker school of oratory. He has been so amusing so far that I want to ask him a question so that he can continue for a little while.
He came here in 1988. He is telling us all the wonderful things that have gone on with Canada Post. He does not remember the days prior to that when Canada Post was running a deficit of almost $1 billion. He does not remember when 70 per cent of complaints in member's offices were about Canada Post from the citizens of this country who were not getting service and turnaround time.
Now we have a corporation that we can be truly proud of. It is finally showing a profit, finally being productive and putting forward a real effort to deliver on time. Ninety-nine per cent of the mail is now delivered on time. It is showing a profit.
My question to the hon. member is does he not realize that when he talks about the ultimate privatization of Canada Post, by selling to the employees 10 per cent it will make it almost impossible for anyone else to buy it? Who are you going to sell it to? You offer it to someone and they say: "We do not want to buy it, 10 per cent is owned by the employees. We cannot buy it".
His argument is totally out of whack. I really did enjoy the hand waving and the George Baker school of oratory style. Please continue and please try to answer that question.

If the hon. member enjoyed the performance, perhaps he should have also listened to the content of what I said because the content was much better than the performance.
The content was absolutely factual and the hon. member opposite knows that. The hon. member can go back. If the hon. member thinks that they have done such a great job at Canada Post, I would invite him to see how many Canada Post employees he can get at his next rally if he were running again. I will show you that those Canada Post employees would not be on the inside of the hall. They would be on the outside of the hall with placards, where they were the last time after four years of Tory government in 1988.
I want to clarify something. The hon. member opposite would have us believe that I think profit is a dirty word. On the contrary, good management practices have to be promoted and, where established, recognized. There have been some substantial changes in Canada Post. Some have been extremely positive. Unfortunately, some have been absolutely devastating, mostly the ones affecting the employees of Canada Post.
May 15, 1992

The Canada Post corporation is also in the business of delivering something else which is not a dirty word and it is called service. What I seek is only a balance. I seek cost effectiveness in the delivery of the service but I also seek the delivery of service. I understand that as a Crown corporation it has a responsibility when it is owned by the federal government to try to equalize to the best of its ability, to try to equalize the level that is given, no matter where you live in Canada. That clearly is not the case now.
If the hon. member opposite believes that Canada Post just delivers letters and that is it, then he should talk to some of the people from Rural Dignity of Canada who came up here and met with his caucus. They met with the caucus of the New Democratic Party and they met with our caucus. They talked about the role of the post office in their communities. Every time they came and did that, it fell on deaf ears.
The other thing I want to say is basically that Canada Post offers good service. It is not the middle-level management and it is not the regional manager I have down in Nova Scotia. The regional manager has now been transferred to Toronto and he is one heck of a fine gentleman. He works as best he can with the restrictions that are put on him by the policies decided at the top. As a Crown corporation, the policy directive comes directly from the cabinet table through the minister responsible. That is where it comes from.
Oh, come on.

The hon. member opposite says: "Oh, come on". He knows full well that when people are hired by Governor in Council they take orders by Governor in Council. He knows that is the case.
In conclusion, profit is not a dirty word. Neither is service, respect nor recognition for the great service that the employees, the men and women of Canada Post, have given to the Canadian public.

Madam Speaker, as the hon. member alluded earlier, he and I served together on one of the House of Commons standing
Government Orders
committees which spent six or seven months looking into Canada Post and its operations. It came up with a fairly comprehensive set of recommendations for the future of Canada Post. One of those recommendations did in fact deal with the privatizing of the corporation.
My own personal position is in favour of that for this reason. If Canada Post could be privatized and then regulated by an independent, third party agency similar to the CRTC and the way the CRTC regulates the telephone monopoly in this country, perhaps we might have more accountability in terms of the operations of Canada Post. Perhaps there would be a mechanism whereby communities, unions or anyone else in this country interfacing with the post office might be able to go to an independent, decision-making third party or independent agency which would then be able to regulate the affairs of Canada Post.
I would like to know whether the member would see any merit in that particular reform of Canada Post and whether he might in fact see some real good coming out of a structural repositioning of Canada Post as I have just described.

Madam Speaker, I am quite familiar with the hon. member's views on this point. I believe he is truly interested in trying to have a more efficient Canada Post corporation.
I am not opposed to measures that would see a more efficient Canada Post corporation. I am certainly not opposed to any measure that would see greater reportability as well by the corporation to the Government of Canada for the people of Canada.
The current problem we have, as the hon. member knows, is that it is like trying to find hen's teeth at times to get answers out of the senior officers of Canada Post. Every time we ask them a question they hide under commercially sensitive data. We do not know what half the decisions are, unless we sit around the cabinet table.
The one thing I am against is establishing bench-marks of absolute profitability for every service delivered. It is just like user pay. When the government opposite talks about instituting user pay, it is wonderful if you are in an area where fees can be kept low. It is wonderful if you are in an urban area, but God help you if you live out in

May 15, 1992
Government Orders
the backwash somewhere. God help you if you live in a small community.
We know dam well that if we get into privatization of postal services, the next thing that will happen is that the services in the outer reaches of the country will diminish. Toward the centre and in the larger centres services will increase because that is where the money is made.
That is what a watch-dog would take care of.

I hear the hon. member opposite. Let us get real here. Once we start dealing with the private sector, there are way too many members of Parliament who are lobbied far too heavily by high-priced lawyers and lobbyists in Ottawa.
The hon. member shakes his head. He should have sat down lately at the consumer and corporate affairs committee and listened to the banks wailing that they are not making enough money when they made $3.4 billion in profits. He should see the effect they have on government members opposite whenever any changes are proposed in any of the committees of Parliament dealing with their preferred position.
He knows as well as he knows his own name that the corruptness of the political system allows that as long as political parties are financed by private sector donations, the private sector companies that have the donations to give are going to seek a day of atonement.
I would like to see a Canada Post Corporation that has a renewed mandate to provide a certain level of service and that that certain level of service is delivered right across this country according to those standards in the most cost-effective manner possible. That is what I would like to see. In terms of those new areas it is getting into to provide a better service to Canadians like a private courier service, I would like to see it get the heck out of there.
Here is one of the problems we had. He talks about getting into the private sector. I personally would like to know how much money Canada Post lost on its courier service last year. I happen to know that almost every national courier service in Canada last year lost big bucks. I want to find out whether or not that competing priority courier service lost money. If it did, why in the
name of goodness are people paying for it when they go and lick a stamp to mail a first-class letter?
The member opposite talks about the private sector. That is what starts happening when we have Crown corporations with national mandates to provide levels of service and they start tinkering with the private sector where they really should not be.
The hon. member has raised a number of interesting points. He talked about privatizing this and privatizing that. Perhaps he tells us the true agenda of the back bench and the front bench as well.
In conclusion, no, I am not for privatization. I am for the efficient management of the Canada Post corporation and fair treatment of its employees.

Madam Speaker, I welcome this opportunity to speak to Bill C-73. The constituents of Saint-Laurent-Cartierville are concerned about the fact that this legislation does nothing to improve postal services. This bill, which amends the Canada Post Corporation Act, is merely a first awkward attempt at privatization.
To quote my colleague from Glengarry-Prescott- Russell, even Margaret Thatcher had the good sense not to privatize the British postal service.
Instead of building a postal system able to meet the needs of a country the size of Canada, the Conservatives are now destroying another Canadian institution, an institution that maintains links between all the regions of our country.

Liberals and in fact all Canadians do not want to see the privatization of Canada Post, which is something the bill does through the back door. In fact this bill is not even attracted to those people who would like to see Canada Post privatized.
The fact that this proposed legislation only allows employees to acquire non-voting shares is an attack on the rights of postal employees. By only giving the employees non-voting shares the government is denying them the right to have any direct input into policy-making decisions or administrative functions and is preventing them from being on the board of directors.
May 15, 1992



Madam Speaker, unfortunately, this bill does nothing to improve postal services for the people of this country. Canadians want our postal system to improve its delivery of postal services.

Canada Post is one of a long list of institutions that this government has gutted. It has limited home delivery by setting up supermailboxes. It has viciously attacked the fibre of our rural areas by eliminating many local post offices. It is little wonder Canadians are going through a type of identity crisis.
Members on the other side are convinced that the best way to build our nation is by destroying and dismantling the very things that bind us as a nation.
The government has wounded VIA Rail. It has slashed the CBC and it has begun the privatization of Canada Post. Members on this side of the House will never stand for this kind of action. We will oppose it because it is bad for Canada Post and because it is not in the interests of all Canadians.
We have to wonder why this government did not take the opportunity when it introduced this legislation to address all the problems involved with Canada Post.
All of us on this side of the House are in touch with our constituents and realize that the problems of this Crown corporation have to be addressed with the best interests of all Canadians in mind.
The minister responsible for Canada Post said that he believed this plan would be good for morale at the corporation. His argument is that if morale at the post office would improve then the service would improve. I have news for this minister. The employees who he claims will be thrilled because of this legislation have said no thanks. The union has said that the best shares in Canada Post are their wages. The employees want to have a new contract that will respect their needs and rights.
I am particularly concerned that this bill will do nothing about the conversions and closures of post
Government Orders
offices that have caused so many problems around the country.
While money might be the only thing on the government's mind, I believe that in this country the post office is an essential public service. I feel that we must provide equally efficient and proper service throughout the country.
I urge the government to take this opportunity to address the problems associated with a postal service that is only interested in looking at the bottom line, and I am not talking about the postal code. We need to put people first. If this government is not willing to take on that challenge, those of us on this side of the House are.

Postal services are essential to everyone in this country, from the business community in large urban centres to the child living in a remote part of this immense continent. The government can hardly expect this bill to do anything to solve the problems facing our post offices across the country.
The intentions behind Bill C-73 may, and I stress the word "may", be good, but there is considerable uncertainty among those directly concerned by this legislation. There is every indication that once we start going this route, other measures will follow and there will be no turning back.
Giving employees a chance to buy shares in the Canada Post Corporation may be praiseworthy in itself, but I must admit I find it very hard to believe the government is acting in good faith.
Does it really expect to be taken seriously when it says: "Sure, you can buy shares and you will be really part of Canada Post, but no voting rights, so no say in decision making".

Can anyone in this House possibly imagine what the shareholders of any major company would say if they were presented with such a proposal? Does anyone seriously believe that people who have put up their hard earned money, the ones who have accepted to foot the bill, must be muzzled when decisions are taken?
It is simply ridiculous that members opposite would take such action. No one can afford to purchase shares

May 15, 1992
Government Orders
and then simply defer all the major decisions that directly impact on their financial well-being, especially with this Treasury Board and cabinet.
I do not know a single investor who would be willing to sit back hoping everything will go well and knowing that when things turn sour whatever he has to say will go nowhere because his voting power is nil.

It is pretty obvious the Conservative government is trying to get out of the fix it is in by selling shares to Canada Post employees. Canadians know for a fact that something is definitely wrong at Canada Post. However, to let them pay the bill without giving them any power or guarantees in return is rather close to being obscene.

We do not only have to debate the philosophical implications of this bill. We must also discuss the practical. When embarking on this kind of venture I believe Parliament must be provided with the specifics. To be frank, this bill does not provide us with any details at all.
We have to ask ourselves why this legislation does not disclose the value of the Canada Post corporation. How are we as parliamentarians supposed to know the value of the shares being sold? We know that it is 10 per cent, but 10 per cent of what?
We also have no idea how much each share will be worth. We have no idea how accessible this program will be to the average worker at Canada Post. If there are very few shares then this will not benefit the employees of the corporation to any great measure. If on the other hand, the number of shares put into public hands grows quite large the fears of the Canadian public and the members of the Liberal Party that this ideologically driven Conservative Party will privatize Canada Post would have been realized.
Liberals oppose the privatization of Canada Post. We believe that essential public services such as mail delivery belong in public hands.
I think that members on the other side must forget exactly how vast this country is. They forget that profit motive does not take into account service in very remote parts of our country. How does this government intend
to guarantee continued, high quality service to the northern parts of Quebec and the territories if the private sector is allowed to take over this essential public service? That is why we opposed the recommendations of the consumer and corporate affairs committee when it tried to privatize Canada Post. It is very difficult to understand the committee's recommendation. It is very difficult to understand why it recommends an eventual privatization of the corporation while at the same time it says that industrial relations must be improved first.
When one considers the fact that the Canadian Union of Postal Workers is fundamentally opposed to the privatization of Canada Post one must question the government's commitment to improving labour-management relations.
As I mentioned earlier, such an action contributes to the destruction of our national symbols. It is destroying the ties that bind Canada into one nation. Even the actions of the corporation in recent years have shied away from promoting the national nature of Canada Post.
People in my constituency of Saint-Laurent-Cartier-ville have asked me to explain why the maple leaf and the Canadian flag have disappeared from our mail boxes. They have been asking me why they have disappeared from all material related to Canada Post. What do we have now to represent our national postal carrier? To tell the truth I am not exactly sure what it is. I think it is an envelope with wings, but I am not sure.
If the intent of this bill is to improve morale at the post office it is clear that the bill is completely ineffective. If the government was truly interested in improving morale, it would insist on improving labour-management relations by dealing fairly and equitably with the employees of Canada Post.
If the objective of Bill C-73 is to improve the quality of service we get at the post office it has clearly failed. There is absolutely nothing there. Not only has the service not improved, but the corporation is also losing money.
We must conclude that this is the first step in privatization, something that the minister responsible for Canada Post said he clearly supports. We in the Liberal party clearly condemn this action and we will fight it.



Madam Speaker, when Canadians look back on the years when this government was in power, they will remember mostly what it destroyed, starting with VIA Rail, which practically made this country, to our postal services, a means of communication that is still available to all Canadians, whatever their income or social status.
Canadians will remember high taxes, jobs that were lost and promises that were forgotten. And above all, they will remember elected representatives who failed to represent them. It is high time to put Canada back on track, and we in the Liberal Party intend to do so after the next election.

Madam Speaker, it is a sad day when we have to speak once again against a bill by the government, such as Bill C-73, which is selling off an essential government service.
We are told that the purpose of this bill is to make 10 per cent of Canada Post's non-voting shares available for purchase by Canada Post employees on a voluntary basis. We are not told what the shares are worth in dollars. We know what they are worth in dignity or voting power. They are worth absolutely nothing. TTiey are non-voting shares.
What Canada Post is doing is pretending to give the workers a share of control of the management of the company in which they work. That share of control is, taken in itself, a worthy goal and it is one that the Ontario government supports. However, the Ontario government does not try to cheat the workers out of having a voting share in the company if they buy shares in that company. It does not try to con them into thinking that by holding non-voting shares they have some power over their working conditions, over their wages and over the future of their jobs. That is what this government is trying to do. It is trying to con the workers and trying to con the public.
The government probably has two purposes in this. One is to further stall the labour negotiations which are already disgracefully late. It has been nearly three years that Canada Post has held its employees without a contract. This presumably is meant to change the agenda so that we do not talk any more about labour relations;
Government Orders
we talk about employees getting gold stars if the supervisor looks on them with favour.
We are told that by giving the employees the dignity of being shareholders they will work better. We are also told that they are fine employees and they are working very well now. In other words, the government has not got its story together correctly.
I agree that the employees are good workers. There are some who live in my constituency, and when they come to me with their complaints I can size them up as people who have worked there for years and decades and want to serve the public but are frustrated. Sometimes they are immigrants who are being shabbily treated on the midnight shift by a supervisor, but who sincerely want to work and have a good record in the community in terms of their character. I know that these employees are good employees that want to serve the public. They do not need to be given gold stars or meaningless shares.
We are not told what the shares are worth in dollars if an employee wanted to sell them, for example. We are not told what Canada Post is worth. What is 10 per cent of a question mark? It is a sham and a fraud, but it is in keeping with the past history of Canada Post and its dishonest dealings with the Canadian Union of Postal Workers.
The idea that this will improve the service to urban and rural constituencies is a sick joke.
The government pooh-poohs the idea that this is a step toward privatization. Yet the minister was quoted in The Ottawa Citizen, and I am not aware that he has repudiated this quote, and the article says: "Andre insisted that immediate privatization is not in the cards". We buy that. He did not immediately privatize Air Canada when he started selling shares to the employees, that was just the first of several steps toward privatizing. He let the cat out of the bag when he said that there is no immediate privatization.
The minister went on to say: "There are no plans either on the table or buried in a desk anywhere to bring forward a privatization of the post office". However, he then refused to say that there would not be any privatization. To say: "We do not have any plans" emphasizes that it is not going to be tomorrow or the next day but it could be farther down the road.
The Ottawa Citizen story goes on to say:
He refused to rule out future privatization-except to say that
nothing will happen until after the next election.

We understand what those promises mean. The Prime Minister made a famous promise to maintain unemployment insurance without change or reduction. Yet immediately after the last election he reneged on that promise and slashed unemployment insurance, destroying a program that had existed in this country for nearly half a century and on which working people depend.
If we will just believe the Prime Minister and the minister in charge of the post office until the next election, then they will do whatever they had planned to do all along.
He admits that. He thinks they can get away with making it a joke. He said:
If I had to bet I would bet that in the next couple of decades you will
see post offices being privatized all over the world and I would not
mind seeing Canada first.
That is like the famous boast of the Prime Minister when he said: "Give us 20 years and you will not recognize Canada". He has not even taken 20 years to destroy some of our best institutions, such as VIA Rail and Canada Post, and he has not even taken 20 years to seriously damage the health system and post-secondary education by cutting back on the federal government's commitment to share in those costs.
It could well be that selling these shares to some willing employees is an attempt to make a future private industry profit-oriented buyer more willing to buy Canada Post with the idea that the employees are tame. There are some gold star receiving employees who will do whatever they are asked to do and will not ask to have a union. Right now they have a union but the union has no contract. Perhaps Canada Post is waiting not just for the next election but for the final destruction and disappearance of all unions within Canada Post's jurisdiction in order to make it easier to sell.
The fact that it likes to remove Canadian emblems from visibility on Canada Post property certainly encourages the suggestion that the buyer that the government might very well prefer would be an American one, perhaps one of the American courier corporations who are already operating in Canada.
One of my colleagues said, jokingly: "Why not privatize the fire department?" As a matter of fact, it is not quite a joke. There is an historical precedent for privatizing a fire service. In ancient Rome there was a man called Marcus Crassus, an entrepreneur and a smart man, who organized a fire brigade. When a house caught
fire Crassus and his men would come on the run carrying buckets and towing a big tank of water. Crassus then would begin to negotiate with the owner of the house to buy it. If the owner thought his price was too low and began arguing with Crassus that it should be higher, then he could stand watching his house bum down while they argued about the price. If the owner finally agreed to Crassus' price, perhaps Crassus by that time had dropped his price, but if they finally agreed on his price then Crassus became the owner of the burned down house. Crassus became perhaps the largest landowner in the city of Rome in his time. He certainly became what we would call a multimillionaire, if not a billionaire.
However, I do not think that service is a model we would want to follow. Just letting private citizens' homes bum down is one thing, but if we were going to let the major buildings in the centre of Toronto or in the centre of Ottawa, or, Heaven help us, the Parliament Buildings, bum down, I do not think that the Crassus system would really be equal to the occasion. We must have certain public services that are provided by the elected representatives, with the money the elected representatives collect from the public, with whatever cost recovery is reasonable.
In other words, the first object of a service such as the fire brigade or the post office is to provide service to the public. The first object of the post office is to deliver mail to all Canadians because all Canadians are taxpayers. It is not merely to deliver mail first to those who can pay the most for it and let the others wait or not merely to give a low-priced service in the high density areas and let the people in the country pay far higher prices on somebody's reckoning of cost benefit.
The gambit of offering these shares to the employees as a move toward privatization is a dishonest one, especially against the record of this government. I do not believe people will trust the government with that any more than they trust it now.
It is said this is supposed to give us labour-management peace. That shows a 19th century attitude. They may be talking about 20th century or 21st century technology but the brains on the government side are locked in the 19th century, when owners believed they had a right to refuse any union representation among their employees, and they often used violent methods to enforce that so-called right.

Canada Post has the worst record in Canada as a bad and dishonest employer toward its employees. It has racked up an incredible total of 100,000 outstanding grievances. Some of those grievances have been entered by constituents who have come to me to ask me to help. They know their union is trying but with 100,000 grievances blocking the road, the chances of getting a reasonable, early and just settlement are pretty dim.
I believe that Canada Post was willing to have those grievances pile up in order to force the union out on strike. The grievance procedure is half a century old, developed first in the United States and then in all parts of Canada. The grievance procedure is an essential part of modern labour relations so that employees do not have to go on a wildcat strike in order to get an injustice rectified.
There is a procedure. You start with a steward and so on. You work up. Eventually you go to arbitration. In return for that procedure, plus other key matters such as seniority clauses, the union signs a contract. Even without seniority clauses, that procedure, at least in the province of Ontario and I believe in the other provinces, is part of the law. It is based on the law that there shall be a procedure of that sort although the details of it vary from contract to contract.
Without that procedure no union in its right senses would sign a contract. What the union gives in a contract is the guarantee that there will be no work stoppage during the life of the contract. That is the labour peace that is bought by union contract.
The most dynamic employers of our country such as the auto industry well understand the efficiency and the financial value to the owners of signing a contract. It does not mean they agree to everything the union wants. The union does not get everything it asks for. The company does not get everything it asks for.
Both sides understand that they have to make cars. They have to have an orderly work process and so they settle on a contract, sometimes with a short strike, but not with the kind of dishonesty that Canada Post has displayed in the handling of a strike. Canada Post advertised for casual workers and swore up and down it did not intend to use them for strike-breakers which was all it was intending to use them for. It hired helicopters
Government Orders
to bring the mailbags in and out of the sorting station in eastern Toronto, paying non-unionized Canada Post employees their room, board and travel expenses to replace unionized staff and so on.
These are dishonest strike-breaking practices which I hope before too long will be outlawed in the province of Ontario, as some of them are outlawed in the province of Quebec.
So a company cannot run its business.

Mr. Speaker, the hon. member is afraid that somebody might go on strike. There is that possibility. There is also the possibility that the company will violate the contract and force a union out on strike. The union has two recourses against violation of the contract by the company. One is the grievance procedure which the management of Canada Post has destroyed by blockading it. The other is the right to strike at the appropriate legal time, which is what the union followed.
The company not only showed its bad faith in the time leading up to and during the strike, but Canada Post showed particularly bad faith in the settlement of the strike. It was proposed by go-betweens that there should be a resolution, that the union would come back to work and that an arbitrator would be imposed because both Canada Post and the union said there were only about seven, eight or nine items left of dozens and dozens that had been on the table in dispute.
The union not only agreed to come back to work, it sent out the word to its members to come back to work as soon as possible. Many of them came back before the deadline. They wanted to demonstrate their good faith in getting the post office working again.
After the arbitrator was appointed, management withdrew what it had already agreed as part of the offer. That was thoroughly dishonest. Six months later there is still no contract. There is now this gimmick to try to put the union entirely out of the picture.
There is no way that the employees of Canada Post are going to trust the management that destroys its union contract by violation and by outright deception. There is no way they are going to trust them in return for gold stars or a gimmick like that which are used in some companies to set one worker against another to try to

Government Orders
undermine the morale of a union. There is no way that there will be industrial peace.
What the Canada Post management and the minister in charge probably want is a complete breakdown of the post office. It seems to me that they are pushing it for all their worth.
They brag that there is 90 per cent efficiency in first day delivery. Many people that I know seem to be among the 10 per cent that cannot get it, including myself. I know that parcel post has deteriorated greatly since it was farmed out to little stores around the district instead of using the two post offices on Spadina Avenue, as they did before. Parcels are not delivered. They come back marked "not open" when mailed to an office that is open every business day of the week. We have to wait weeks to find out where the parcel is. Then we have to go around to some other part of town to get that parcel. It is a most inefficient system that has been brought in.
Nobody believes the claim of 90 per cent efficiency. Sometimes we have a happy surprise and there is next day delivery, that is true. You cannot make the employees work with a system that is being disrupted by the closing of post offices, disrupted by giving services away to competitors, disrupted by using patronage to give little sub-post offices to stores that often are not equipped either to store or to handle the mail efficiently. There is no way that post office will work. The first thing to do is settle that contract with the union and then go on from there.

Mr. Speaker, this bill is an initiative to try and improve relations between the management at Canada Post and the employees, the labour group.
It is no surprise to most Canadians that the NDP and other political agents of big labour are opposed to any initiative that offered hope of real management and labour co-operation or team building.
One of the primary objectives of the union movement, one of the main purposes of the union and the NDP, is to stimulate conflict in the labour place, in the work place.
While the union-controlled NDP publicly supports the notion of improved labour relations, the secret constitution of the Canadian Union of Postal Workers, the national constitution adopted in 1990, tells a different story.
This NDP supported document reveals the true motives of the NDP and the union movement. On page 2, A-5, it says: "The union views as a primary direction of accomplishment of workers is to control the work place. This principle ensures that the union and its members will seek at all junctures to limit the power of the employer to organize our jobs, the methods of production and planning our work, or otherwise discipline our members. In its place the union will seek for its members full control of the work they perform and the environment in which they perform work".
In addition on page 12 it says with regard to industrial democracy, something you might find in Beijing or Tiananmen Square a couple of years ago: "Because the union recognizes the power of the labour movement and of our union rests on the collective strength of its members, and because the union views the interests of workers as conflicting with the interests of employers, the union rejects all forms of industrial democracy and quality of work life schemes promoting the notion of union participation and co-operation in employer programs".
In addition, in terms of co-operation between government, management and employees this is totally rejected by this secret document which the NDP supports.

Mr. Speaker, following on what I said about the opposition of the NDP and the union movement to any form of co-operation whatsoever between government, management, and the workers, confirmation can be found on page 13 of this constitution: "In line with opposition to industrial democracy, the union condemns any and all attempts by labour bodies to establish partnerships between labour and government, or between labour, government, and employers".
"Within the trade union movement the union wants to promote and strengthen a militant and combative front with which to oppose any form of co-operation with management and government serving management's interests".
The most successful economies in the world have demonstrated that the way to become successful is through team work, through working together. We have seen that in Japan, in Germany, particularly the western part of Germany.
We have also seen the result of socialist policies in the former Soviet Union. We have seen the destruction and the degradation of the economy there.
We find that the NDP, through its support and through its control by the union movement rejects any form of co-operation.
We have seen what has gone on in the former Soviet Union.
Would the NDP come clean? Publicly it supports the notion of co-operative efforts between labour and management. It supports the notion publicly of improved relations and teamwork, yet it does not seem to be coming clean with the Canadian people in the sense that it also supports this document, this secret constitution by the union that seems to provide a different story for Canadians.
Which does it support, the idea of conflict and confrontation or the idea of co-operation?

Mr. Speaker, I am very glad to answer that question. I would say the proof of the pudding is in the eating.
In fact, regardless of what quotations the member may choose to select out of a document that he claims is a secret constitution, the fact is that last year, for example, the Canadian Union of Postal Workers attempted to co-operate.
Government Orders
I know that in Toronto the union asked that the old age pensions and other government cheques be made available for distribution before the legal strike date. The post office refused. It asked after the strike had begun on the legal strike date if it would be allowed to deliver them as volunteers. The post office refused.
Instead, the post office set up special stations and invited the public to come and collect its mail. Half the time, according to complaints from my constituents, their mail was not at the stations on the day they were told it would be.
The co-operation in action was on the side of the union, not on the side of the company.
Furthermore, I have experience of my own with a union, the Canadian Paper Workers Union. During the 18 years I worked in a factory I was a shop steward and I was secretary of the local. I took part in grievance bargaining, in contract bargaining. As a delegate to the Labour Council in metropolitan Toronto, I had regular reports from other delegates on the progress of their union affairs.
My point is that the labour movement and the NDP, to the extent that we are affiliated with the labour movement, are trying to get fair and reasonable bargaining. More than 90 per cent of contracts are settled without a strike or even intervention by the government in the way of mediation or arbitration. Of course, that does not hit the newspapers.
During the 18 years I worked at the Continental Can box plant we did not have a strike. But the people who want to blame the unions for all disputes simply do not look at the huge majority of times when the unions are the ones making the concessions in order to get the operation working again.
I am sorry that the hon. member has such a closed mind on the matter.

The hon. member will be missed in this House. He asked a very important question when he began the debate. He asked: What is the government's agenda in bringing this bill forward?
I think I can answer him. The government's agenda is a hidden agenda. It is like many other things the government does in this House. It brings in certain bills but then it has a hidden agenda. The hidden agenda is to dismantle Canada Post Corporation step by step, the heritage of our country.
We saw this when the minister was asked whether this was the first step towards privatization. He said that philosophically, he is not against privatization. This means he is already giving Canadians the signal that this is one of the first steps toward privatization. If it is toward privatization, and I think it will be, there will be post office after post office shut down across the country.
In my own riding I just have two postal outlets, Station M and Station V. Station M has already been reduced in its service. Station V is on the chopping block again. The government wanted to close it two years ago. Those of my constituents who use the post office gathered petitions and I made representations to the minister. We held off the closure for two years, but now rumours are that Station V is back on the chopping block. Why? There is no reason.
Station V is the heartbeat of the community. People come in and they gossip. The post office manager, Mr. Cosy, knows most of the clients. He greets everyone by name practically. What a nice community atmosphere this post office provides.
I was bom and raised in Foston, Saskatchewan. It is called a one-horse town. Today maybe it is a one-car town. I remember as a small boy everyone gathering in the post office and catching up with the news of the community. We later moved to a slightly bigger town called Hendon. It was the same thing there. The post office was the heart of that community too. Then we bought a bigger farm and moved to Wadena, Saskatchewan. Even in this bigger town to this day the post office is the centre of the community. It is the town hall of Wadena.
I want to raise something that no other member has raised. I think the points about improved management-labour relations are a facade.
The minister talked about 76,000 employers and this will strengthen the partnership. This will make the relationships more harmonious. He talked about the esprit de corps that this bill will bring in. How can he think that giving 10 per cent shares, with no value defined yet, with no voting rights for the shareholders, that by throwing this little tidbit it is going to improve management-labour relations?
Come on. These workers know better. They know that this is just a facade. If anything, it will make relations even worse. Let them settle the three years of the collective agreement which has not yet been signed. Let them work on that if they want to improve the esprit de corps.
What is it that I want to raise that no other member has raised? I want to do something about the heritage of Canada because if these post offices in the small villages are going to be closed one by one, we are going to have yet another bit of Canada's heritage wiped off the scene.
We spend a lot of time debating what should go into the Constitution and how to keep this country together. Well, let us not dismantle it. Here is our heritage.
When I was a member here between 1979 and 1984,1 brought in a private member's bill to preserve the old railway stations. If you recall, one morning, without telling anyone, CP came and bulldozed down the railway station in west Toronto near my riding. After I left, Mr. Taylor from the Conservative Party picked up that bill, reintroduced it and it was subsequently passed.
It was thanks to the initiative of two private members, myself and Mr. Taylor on the Conservative side that the railway stations across this land are now preserved. Companies cannot tear them down without going to the public, to the community, holding hearings, looking at alternatives, before touching that building.
I am recommending to the government in my portion of debate that if it is going to go this route, and I hope it does not, but if the Prime Minister and the government want to destroy another part of Canada, let the government bring in legislation that will preserve all of the old historical post offices from coast to coast to coast to the

U.S. border. If it does not bring in that legislation, another bit of Canada goes down the drain.
If I can make any contribution in this speech, and I do not want to repeat everything that has been said before, I just want to emphasize. Be Canadian, Mr. Prime Minister. You say you love Canada. Show it.
I do not think we should play games and waste time with a private member's bill for that important legislation. I am tossing a challenge to the government to bring in a government bill to protect the post offices across this country.

Mr. Speaker, I listened with interest and some fascination to the hon. member's comments.
During the period of time that I was chairman of the House of Commons consumer and corporate affairs committee we conducted a study into the history and the future of Canada Post and the postal service in this country.
I recall distinctly two of the witnesses who appeared before the committee were historians. They had recently completed a study on the history of mail delivery and mail service in Canada.
I was struck by the fact that the vast majority of postal outlets historically in Canada were located in private enterprises. They were located either in people's homes or general stores, almost without exception in rural Canada.
Canada Post in its former incarnation as a department of the federal government almost without exception in small communities operated in the private sector. It was only in a few of the large Canadian cities that there were what we would now term to be corporate-owned postal outlets, in other words buildings erected by the Government of Canada, or the governments of Upper or Lower Canada at the time, and operated by those governments.
So I think the member is really not being true to his history when he talks about the need to preserve government-owned post offices because they are historic monuments. Well, history does not bear that out.
Canada Post in its former incarnation started out in the private sector providing services to small communities in storefronts and in people's homes. It is an interesting devolution that has gone on where again Canada Post is abandoning a philosophy of having a large corporate-owned structure and going back into the small
Government Orders
enterprises, which often and ironically are open for longer hours and provide better service.
I am wondering if the member could give us his comments on that piece of history?

I do not know who these historians were but I am sure their research must have been dependent on what period of Canada's history they were looking at. If you go back far enough in the history of our postal service, you go back to the pony express. Now, I am not asking that the pony express be reincarnated here. But I am asking that our heritage be preserved through all the stages of history, from the pony express to priority post today, which cannot deliver a letter for me on a long weekend.
A year ago today I went to the local post office to send a letter to Ottawa. The recipient did not have a fax or anything fancy, but I had to get the letter there for Monday. I went into the post office late Friday. The post office apologized because Saturday the workers were gone, Sunday nothing moved and Monday was a holiday. The postal workers told me to go to a private postal delivery service to deliver my letter from Toronto to Ottawa.
This is indeed ironic when we hear the minister and other members boasting about how efficient the system is now. That is how efficient it is.
The hon. member who spoke earlier this morning talked about finding mail in the swamp. I sent out a lot of letters one December and two never arrived. A year later, two of those letters were returned to me in Ottawa. I guess those letters were floating in the swamp that the hon. Conservative member was talking about. Let us not play games.
Getting back to the heritage of Canada, I am glad the hon. member is interested in this. Maybe he can convince his Prime Minister and his ministers responsible to bring in such legislation. Knowing how aggressive he is, maybe he will do it himself.

In fairness to the member for Trinity-Spadina, getting together at the same time was really the difficulty. I did not stop doing it because he worked for Continental Can.
