speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I might say I am pleased today to rise in this House to respond to the motion of my hon. friend from Regina-Lumsden.
As the House will know, I have had occasions in the past to share many debates on many important issues with my hon. friend from the opposite side of the House.
The member opposite from Regina-Lumsden has once again spoken eloquently on this subject. This is no surprise to anyone who has listened to him over these many years in this House of Commons. This Chamber, I might add, has been in awe of his prestigious memory regarding transportation issues.
I can speak from experience on my own part from the many years we have spent on opposite sides in the transportation committee. I would use the phrase a worthy opponent as being the most appropriate way of describing our relationship.

May 15, 1992
Private Members' Business
It will come as no considerable surprise, though, that I would speak against this motion and take a different tack on it than what the member opposite has said. As I have said in the past, we have often found ourselves on opposite sides on such positions. This does not however diminish my own admiration for my hon. colleague, and I am glad to have an opportunity to say so in the Chamber this afternoon.
The hon. member today is speaking about the government going out and playing a greater part in terms of infrastructure. It would almost seem he is alluding to the fact that the government has not had any part in the infrastructure in our country, but this is simply not the case. We have in the past contributed money to help provinces and occasionally local governments with infrastructure, construction and maintenance.
Highways in fact have been traditionally an area where the federal government spends money to help other levels of government with infrastructure construction. Over the years the federal money has paid for a lot more than the road and bridge repairs envisioned in the hon. member's resolution.
The House well knows that the vast majority of roads is not federal jurisdiction. Indeed road mileage under direct federal control amounts to less than 3 per cent of the national total, and these are mostly in our national parks and on aboriginal lands.
The federal government for one reason or another also owns a number of significant bridges, mostly connecting Canada with the United States. Of the 97 per cent of Canadian highway mileage out of federal jurisdiction, almost two-thirds is under municipal and local control. The hon. member opposite has alluded to the fact that he is talking about the infrastructure within the municipal structure.
I might add that despite the fact highways are outside our federal purview, federal government contributions to highways go back a long way. The very first highway assistance program was established by Parliament in 1919 with the object of stimulating construction and co-ordinating provincial activity to achieve some uniformity in highway standards. This program lapsed in 1928.
Subsequently highway construction was a significant component of federal relief programs in the 1930s. It was during this period that work started on the Trans-Canada Highway. Serious work on the Trans-Canada however did not get going until after the Second World War. Parliament passed the Trans-Canada Highway Act in 1949 and initiated the era of major federal-provincial highway cost sharing programs. The Trans-Canada alone cost the federal government over $800 million before the act lapsed at the end of 1970. By that time, highway cost-sharing programs had become a fact of Canadian life.
I will not bore you or this House with a litany of all the programs which the federal and other levels of government undertook over the years, but a few bear mentioning. There were the Roads to Resources and the Atlantic Trunk Road programs in the 1960s and the regional development agreements in the 1970s. Over the years, all regions of the country have benefited from one or the other of these programs.
This brings me to where we are now and what we are doing. At present there are a number of federal departments and agencies involved in highway construction. Basically they can be divided into two groups: the builders and the funders. The builders include public works, environment and the National Capital Commission. These are directly involved in road construction on federal land. The main funding department these days is Transport Canada.
At present, Transport Canada oversees programs involving cost-sharing agreements with the Atlantic provinces and Quebec. A further program which provided money for improvements to the Yellowhead Highway and involved agreements with the four western provinces expired in 1991.
Generally speaking, the programs fall into the following categories: regional development programs, including economic and regional development agreements or ERDAs; co-operation agreements with the provinces of Prince Edward Island, Quebec, Newfoundland and Labrador; highway improvement programs with Nova Scotia and New Brunswick; and the specific Newfoundland transportation initiative. These programs collectively
May 15, 1992

amount to a federal commitment of over $1 billion in funding spread out over a number of years.
The highway improvement agreements with Nova Scotia and New Brunswick expire in 1995-96. The ERDAs run to 1994-95. The Newfoundland initiative is until the year 2003.
In all, the federal government has averaged around $230 million a year in highway spending over the past decade. All provinces have received some of this money, with the bulk of it going to the provinces most in need of it.
As the recent federal budget indicated, the time may come for the federal government once again to launch a program to develop further our national highway system. I would certainly welcome such a program, primarily for the economic benefit it would bring in the form of a more efficient system for both domestic distribution and exports. This is really much in line with what the hon. member opposite has been proposing.
Even without a new program, however, the federal government is involved in highway construction and at levels beyond that envisioned in the resolution that is before us.
Although the hon. member's aims are worthy and I have no doubt about his sincerity, I was beginning to wonder at what stage of history he was going to take us back to, but he only took us back today to the 1950s. Many a time he has done this with us in the transport committee over the years. Rarely have we ever caught him out on his facts either. The member has failed today to take into account the current programs. For this reason, I will not be supporting this motion.
In closing, I would once again want to salute my hon. friend opposite for what he has contributed today to this debate. I also want to wish him the very best in the treatments that he is undergoing at this time for his health.

Mr. Speaker, first let me start by congratulating the member for his motion. Certainly the Liberal Party, when we looked at this issue back in the early days of 1988 and before, was the only national party that not only supported the idea of providing help to municipalities, but we had put a dollar and cent figure on it. We were the only national party that committed a $15 billion fund to be put toward infrastructure across Canada. That was done as a result
Private Members' Business
of a request which was made by the Federation of Canadian Municipalities. That was not the case for the NDP. The NDP did not have a program, did not support a program, nor did it even want to talk about a program of partnership. However, my colleague's motion is a good one. Perhaps he has moved that extra necessary step.
Back in 1990 as a result of a request that was put by my colleague from Nepean and myself to our leader, the Liberal Party of Canada has launched a task force. This task force has travelled almost in every province and territory across Canada in order to meet with community leaders, business leaders, environmental and special interest groups to find out what they want us as a party to do in order to move forward with the question of infrastructure.
I would like to put on the record some of the recommendations that the Liberal task force has brought forward. Those recommendations at the time were endorsed by the Federation of Canadian Municipalities.
While we believe that no single action will be enough to ensure the future health and viability of Canada's infrastructure, we believe that a broad range of measures is necessary to make a meaningful difference.
Our recommendations include:
a federal recognition of municipal infrastructure as a crisis of national proportion;
a federal commitment to share the responsibility for municipal infrastructure with the provincial and municipal counterpart;
the establishment of a minimum national criteria for infrastructure to provide environmental protection and a uniform level of services for all Canadians, so we will not see ourselves in the same situation every 15 or 20 years and we will set those standards and then we will make sure that our partners are meeting those standards;
a federal commitment to rehabilitate and expand the Trans-Canada Highway; and
the establishment of a process through which the federal government can take action. This includes defining the respective role of federal, provincial and municipal governments in infrastructure construction and management, identifying and priorizing needs on a national scale in consultation with and with the concurrence of provincial and municipal governments.

May 15, 1992
Private Members' Business
It also includes increasing incentives for maintenance and reconstruction of existing capital assets and the use of low capital, environmentally conscious techniques, such as waste reduction and recycling, exploring alternative funding sources including such options as more rational user fees for water services, applying fuel tax revenues to road construction, maintenance and increased private sector involvement.
Finally it includes increasing support for research and development to accelerate technological innovation and encouraging efficient municipal management methods to permit phased programs of rehabilitation, better management of infrastructure systems and effective use of funds.
We have on the record the position of our party when it comes to municipal infrastructure. Also, very recently the opposition leader has put forward a number of points that will help the Canadian economy. One of those points was a federal government involvement in the area of infrastructure.
It has been estimated that in excess of 300,000 jobs can be created as a result of a partnership between the three levels of government. As my colleague indicated earlier, this is an incredible investment in the future of Canadians.
When we talk about infrastructure, we are talking about roads, sewer systems and bridges. Believe it or not, those are the most important ingredients for economic development because industry will not locate in a town that does not have a proper infrastructure.
Housing construction will not take place in a town that does not have sufficient municipal services that would include proper roads, as well as sewer systems, water treatment plants, and so on.
My colleague from Nepean and I, when we were travelling across Canada, heard horror story after horror story from mayors, from councillors, from business people and so on. Every one of them told us quite bluntly that they would not be able to do it alone. They do need the involvement of the other partners, and that is the provincial government as well as the federal government.
Whether we want it or not, there is an environmental spin-off as a result of the federal government's involvement in infrastructure. The environment is at stake here and any federal government involvement in the area of infrastructure would help the environment.
Think in terms of the sewer systems that are leaking into our rivers, our lakes and the oceans. Think in terms of the water treatment plants that are not meeting provincial standards. In Ontario alone there are in excess of 90 different municipalities in which it was found the systems were not up to standard, and they were forced by the provincial government to meet those standards.
I cannot tell the House how devastating the situation is in Atlantic Canada in areas in which there is raw sewage being dumped right into the ocean. I say this and I am at a loss because in situations like this I would say that the federal government should have stepped in a long time ago in order to provide the necessary help and support for those municipalities to implement a proper sewage treatment plant and a proper sewage system.
I was informed as well that in areas such as Newfoundland there are a number of homes, thousands of homes, that do not even have sewer systems. That by itself is quite alarming and that is why the Liberal Party has recognized this issue as a national issue. That is why we are the only party to put forward a tangible proposal and a proper strategic plan that will deal with this question of infrastructure and will deal with the question of partnership among the three different partners.
With that, I would like to close by thanking my colleague who has introduced this motion for providing me as well as other colleagues with the opportunity to put forward the positions of our collective caucuses and our collective parties.

Mr. Speaker, I rise to speak to the motion of the member for Regina- Lumsden on Canadian infrastructure funding.
I support in theory the idea of federal involvement in infrastructure spending but I disagree strongly with the hon. member's approach. I know that he would be very disappointed if I did not.
I have had many discussions. The hon. member for Regina-Lumsden and I had the honour to go to Yugoslavia and Bulgaria a little over a year ago. During our spare time we spent a lot of time discussing transport issues and I bow to his extensive knowledge. Having been
May 15, 1992

in this House since 1968 and having served on the transport committee for many of those years, as my colleague from British Columbia has stated, his facts are very seldom wrong.
As I said before, I disagree with his approach. He seems convinced that with a few repairs here and there and the whole country will benefit. He made a statement that this motion is one of many ways that we can bring about full employment and thereby assist our country and our people.
I am convinced that in these times of severe fiscal constraint the federal government should confine its financial support for infrastructure improvement to areas in which it has identified clear national objectives which will be of lasting value to the country as a whole.
All this is by way of introduction to the national highway policy study, which is an excellent example of how this sort of thing ought to be done.
The federal government has identified highway improvement as an area in which scarce federal resources can be used to best effect. The federal government is now well advanced in studying the most effective way to make a valuable contribution to the national highway infrastructure needs. It is doing so in a rational, carefully considered, non-partisan fashion.
As we all know, highways are a provincial responsibility under the Constitution. Successive federal governments have recognized that highways also have a national economic significance as avenues of interprovincial and international commerce. Federal involvement in highway construction funding goes back a long way to, as the hon. member stated, the early 1920s when it was important to find jobs for our returning soldiers.
In the early 1950s federal participation was essential if Canada was to ever have a Trans-Canada Highway linking east and west. However, by the mid-1980s federal highway policy had been reduced to ad hoc support for various provincial priority highway projects. These were often, as it has been said, local roads which did not have any truly national significance.
Private Members' Business
Work on a comprehensive national highway policy commenced in 1988 and has proceeded through four successive phases. From the beginning this policy development has been a historic federal-provincial co-operative effort, and the major industry's stakeholders have also been consulted at the appropriate points.
In the first phase the criteria for selection of highways comprising a national system of economic importance was established. The system thus identified comprises
25,000	kilometres, which amounts to only 3 per cent of the total Canadian highway network but carries over 75 per cent of freight and 90 per cent of inter-city passenger traffic. Think about that. Three per cent of the total highway network carries 75 per cent of freight and 90 per cent of inter-city passenger traffic. This network links all major cities, ports of entry and other major transportation nodes in our provinces and our territories.
Seventy-five per cent of this system is still two-lane and, incredibly, some portions are still constructed of gravel. When analysed in 1988 over 38 per cent did not meet the minimum national highway engineering standards.
The second phase looked at the economics of the national highway system, in other words, highway related revenue, annual expenditures on capital and maintenance, the potential cost of upgrading and the economic impact of improvements to the system. It was in this phase that both the federal and provincial governments began to get a clear idea of the magnitude of the costs involved.
Effectively, governments were told that to upgrade the system to minimum standards, spending levels on the national highway system would have to double. The total bill now stands at an estimated $14 billion. This total will continue to grow while much needed upgrading is deferred by provincial governments.
The third phase included consultations with the main stakeholders. From this phase it was learned that there was strong industry support for a national highway policy. We also found that the public recognized that additional revenues may be necessary and was even willing to support new taxation, provided that it was dedicated to road improvements. That is food for thought in a country

May 15, 1992
Private Members' Business
in which dedicated taxation is not a common instrument of public policy.
The fourth phase of this study, which has just recently been completed, developed a framework for setting priorities and design and maintenance standards. It also examined principles for cost sharing, and possible preliminary program scheduling.
In summary, we now believe that we are at about the stage at which we know what has to be spent and where it has to be spent. We have now come to the most critical element of all, funding.
At issue are federal-provincial cost sharing and the sources of revenue. Not easy questions for any government, especially in times of fiscal restraint. I have dealt at some length with the national highway policy study because the process seems to me to exemplify how infrastructure issues involving different levels of government should be addressed.
It also shows how the current government has acted on an infrastructure issue which it has identified as being of national economic importance.
This brings me back to the hon. member's motion. What I have described is both more and less than he called for. It is more because it deals with the whole complex process of resolving a particular infrastructure issue, and not just road and bridge repair here and there.
It is less because it has focused on a comparatively narrow area, but it is an area in which federal intervention will have a significant and lasting impact on our national, economic, and social well-being.
I believe that this is the responsible way to treat national infrastructure issues.

Mr. Speaker, I too am pleased to speak to the motion of the member from the New Democratic Party on Canada's infrastructure.
This is probably the third time I have spoken in this House on this issue. Another time it was an opposition day. I and my colleague for Ottawa Centre initiated a study back in 1990 on the state of Canada's infrastructure. As a result of that study we developed this report which was available to anyone who was interested.
This issue is probably one of the most important issues facing Canada today, in terms of how it affects the environment, our deteriorating infrastructure, how it
could affect jobs in this country and reduce unemployment and welfare in the country as a whole.
In travelling across Canada and interviewing many people in many municipalities right across the country it certainly hit home as to how critical the state of the infrastructure is in many, many areas of the country, in particular Atlantic Canada.
On many occasions since 1984 representations have been made to the federal government for the creation of a program to shore up Canada's deteriorating infrastructure. These proposals to date have been ignored by this government.
I do support this private member's motion. It simply reiterates what we already said in our report in 1990. Without a major infusion of funds for the preservation and expansion of bridges, water-mains, roads, and sewers in Canada both the productivity and safety of all Canadians will be jeopardized. A Canada-wide infrastructure program would create more jobs than the trade deal alone. It would help develop every region of the country rather than bail out corporations in select communities as this government has done.
The member who spoke previously asked whether this problem has just been created since 1984. It has been created since 1984 because historically all three levels of government-municipal, provincial and federal-have contributed to the costs of financing urban infrastructure.
From 1938 to 1984 the federal government made funds available for infrastructure programs in this country. Some of the programs included the Municipal Improvement Assistance Act from 1938 to 1949, the Sewage Treatment Program from 1961 to 1974, the Municipal Development and Loan Act from 1963 to 1966, the Neighbourhood Improvement Program from 1973 to 1979, the Municipal Infrastructure Program from 1975 to 1978, and the Community Services Contribution Program from 1979 to 1980.
These were all programs that helped municipalities right across the country. I might say that these programs were all initiated under Liberal governments.
In those years the governments of Canada had been committed to the infrastructure of this country. Today's federal government has refused to accept any share of the responsibility for infrastructure, leaving the munici-
May 15, 1992

pal and provincial governments to struggle with this increasing financial burden.
The government argues that in the Constitution it has no responsibility in the area of infrastructure. It is, however, very important to note that the Constitution does not provide for federal involvement in health care, education or social services. Yet, of course the federal government must be involved in those areas. It must be a major contributor and it is, although it has certainly been reducing that too in recent years.
Therefore, can the federal government deny its responsibility for the environment, clean water, regional and national economic development? When I talk about clean water and I talk about sewage treatment, there has almost been an abdication of political leadership on the part of this government. I am talking about an environmental impact here.
I want to give you an example. The Canadian government spends $3 billion to $4 billion in subsidies on fossil fuels while supposedly fighting for conservation. The same is true with our lobbying for the forestry management. At the same time we are decimating our own resources.
Why not cut these subsidies to an industry which is producing fossil fuels harmful to the environment and use the $2 billion, $3 billion or $4 billion to help with a municipal infrastructure program, reduce the debt or energy conservation? There could be any number of aspects that money could be used for. Do not tell me, fellows, that you do not have any money across the way.
The federal government is not only a badly needed funding partner, but is also in the best position to co-ordinate the establishment of national standards and goals. The federal government is currently levying heavy taxes.
The gentleman across the way just said that there was no way he could get money from whatever. They currently levy heavy taxes on the uses of gasoline and diesel fuel but channel not a cent of these revenues into our road systems. Do not give me that nonsense across the way.
Beyond speech making from the government side of this House we have so far seen little federal commitment to the environment. Our rivers and harbours are pol-
Private Members' Business
luted from Halifax to Vancouver. Beaches are closed summer after summer because the federal government does not make sewer construction and repair a national priority.
It is ironic that under the Great Lakes action plan the federal government has recently announced a $125 million fund for the restoration and preservation of this vital water system. This is in addition to almost $1 billion already spent by the government on the Great Lakes since 1972. Yet we are still pumping raw sewage into the Great Lakes system, and it does not make sense.
There is a cost to doing business and I recognize that. The transportation of goods and services is one important cost to business. Roads in poor condition increase costs, not only through increased use of fuel but through deterioration of vehicles and lost time. Poor roads and lack of waste disposal facilities also add to the cost of doing business, either through increased dump fees or increased costs to have their own waste hauled away.
As governments at all levels start placing stricter environmental controls and ask business to bear the cost of its pollution, business will be able to operate more efficiently in communities that have the infrastructure to handle and treat waste water.
We know that Canadians are the least energy-efficient consumers in the world. Every possible method has to be used to improve our record through sustainable development. The cost of cleaning up our damaged rivers and lakes far exceeds the cost of treating sewage before it gets to these rivers and lakes.
Polluters to date have remained unpunished. The federal government has failed to prosecute a single polluter in the province of Ontario during that last year. That is just disgraceful. The failure to go after polluters has occurred even though Ottawa has the Canadian Environmental Protection Act which carries a maximum penalty of $1 million.
No single action will be enough to ensure the future health and viability of Canada's infrastucture. A broad range of measures is necessary to make a meaningful difference. Specifically, these should include the following:
A federal recognition of municipal infrastructure as a crisis of national proportion;

May 15, 1992
Private Members' Business
A federal commitment to share the responsibility to rebuild infrastructure with its provincial and municipal counterparts;
The establishment of minimal national standards for infrastructure to provide environmental protection and uniform levels of service for all Canadians;
A federal commitment to rehabilitate and expand the Trans-Canada Highway;
The establishment of a process through which the federal government can clarify the respective roles of federal, provincial and municipal governments;
Identify and priorize needs on a national scale; and
Increase incentives for maintenance and reconstruction of capital assets.
We in the Liberal Party have supported this. My leader is on record as supporting a national infrastructure program. I would suggest that this government get serious. If it is not serious about the environment, it has a responsibility to Canadians and to everyone to get people back to work to improve our environment and to get on with the job right away.
It has been a privilege for me to travel across the country and to talk to Canadians. I have heard desolate responses from a lot of people.
I thank the member from the New Democratic Party for putting this motion forward and giving me the opportunity again to speak to this in the House of Commons.

Mr. Speaker, it is indeed an honour to rise in support of the hon. member's motion to provide new funding for the infrastructure of our country.
It is an honour not only because of the substance of the motion that he has put and the wisdom of the suggestion that he makes. It is also an honour for a member of Parliament like myself who has only been in the House for the last three and a half years to rise in recognition of the contribution that the hon. member for Regina-Lumsden has made throughout his political career.
In the province of Saskatchewan, the hon. member for Regina-Lumsden has been known for many things but above all else, he has been known as a gutsy fighter. He
will take on a fight for what he believes is right whether it is popular at the time or not, whether what he has to say is in keeping with the political fashion of the day or not.
He is a member who has always stood by his principles. He has always been prepared to fight the good fight. I think it might be instructive to some of us that this hon. member has been here for 24 years, since 1968. In fact, his courageous and principled stands have not ended up costing him politically. In fact, they have won him respect way beyond the boundaries of the political party he represents, or the constituency that he represents.
The motion which the hon. member has presented today should be seen in that same light. It is not popular nowadays to talk about governments spending money. The popular talk these days is how to slash, how to cut, how to reduce deficits and how to bring down government involvement in providing goods and services in this country.
The hon. member is a student of history. He is a student of economics. He has seen these cycles happen before and he has seen what happens when governments fall prey to the easy wisdom of cutting when times are tough.
The inevitable other end of that cycle is when times get better. Then governments start to spend like crazy and reinforce people's notions about what is possible. Therefore, we are always in a situation where we are doing exactly the opposite of what we should be doing if any kind of economic sense were to prevail.
Certainly, the need has been established for the infrastructure program that the member outlines. Certainly, those of us who have not recognized the need in our own country need only go across the border to the U.S. of A. and see what has happened to their splendid cities since they have introduced the thinking of proposition 13 in California that forbids the raising of taxes at the municipal level to provide the kinds of services that the member is talking about.
The deterioration in those American cities is a scandal to behold. It came as no surprise to any of us who have walked those streets that they should develop the kind of tinder-box situations like we saw in Los Angeles. Certainly, what happened in Toronto is a wake-up call for us to pay attention to those same factors.

If I may just turn briefly to the notion that there is no money, in my constituency of Prince Albert-Churchill River when I first got elected in 1988, the federal share of welfare and UI was $70 million. People were appalled when I raised that figure. They were not aware that it was anywhere close to that.
Now that figure, three and a half years later, has risen to about $125 million in welfare and unemployment insurance costs in one constituency alone. That is the same constituency that has the highest rate of tuberculosis in the country, the highest incidence of infant mortality in the country, much of which is related to inadequate infrastucture.
As well, we need economic development to make taxpayers out of the people now currently on welfare and UI.

Therefore, I would like to conclude by congratulating the member and urging all members to support this motion.
